> What exactly is 'the overhead'?

 Being able to parse a form definition and dynamically decide what to do 
with it (compared to a media-type that simply states "post this to that 
link-reltype, somewhat like AtomPub which does not include form-defs).

> I do not refer to generic forms. A form is any syntactical construct that 
> instructs the user agent what data to include in the submission (including 
> fixed (aka 'hidden')) values. My forms would simply be an inherent part of 
> the specific media type(s) I define.

 Cool, that's what I wanted to hear :-)

> The server need not carelessly send the order to the backend without a 
> check.

 If it can check it - why include it at all? Okay, I know Ian's example - 
its because the target of the form need not have access to the price (it 
could be a completely different system). In this case a check-key/signature 
is a must to avoid tampering.
